bibl.title: Letter from L. O. Howard to Walter Reed, November 21, 1900

div1.p: Howard identifies the mosquito Reed is working as the Culex fasciatus. Howard appreciates answering Reed's questions and considers it a privilege. He then acknowledges receipt of Reed's report and informs Reed of his own upcoming publication. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from L. O. Howard to Walter Reed, November 21, 1900
div1.p:
I have yours of the 16th and the accompanying
specimens. Dr. Coquillett has examined them carefully and finds
that all three specimens have the dorsal silvery stripes, and
are therefore Culex fasciatus according to his tables. He does
not understand how you came to refer one of them to C. taeniatus.
At the time he published his tables he had not seen males of
C. taeniatus, nor had he seen males of some of the other species.
This accounts for the absence of male characterizations of some
of the forms. He thinks there is no doubt as to the classifi-identification
cation of C. fasciatus. I explained in my last letter how he
came to consider the abraded females as being distinct.

Please do not apologize for troubling us. I am intensely
interested in your work and consider it a great privilege to
be permitted to assist you in any way. I received your reprint
of the Preliminary Note. I had already bought a copy of the
“Philadelphia Medical Journal” which contains it, but am glad
to have it in this separate form.

I have just finished my paper on excrement flies. Under
the heading, “A Contribution to the Study of the Insect Fauna
of Human Excrement”, it is to be published in full in the pro-
ceedings of the Washington Academy of Sciences. A summary un-
der some such title as “Flies and Typhoid Fever” will be pub-
lished in Popular Science Monthly and published also in the
